Award.AwardTitle: Carbonyl Sulfide, Methyl Chloride, and Methyl Bromide Measurements in the New Intermediate-depth South Pole Ice Core
Award.AbstractNarration:
In the past, Earth's climate underwent dramatic changes that influenced physical, chemical, geological, and biological processes on a global scale. Such changes left an imprint in Earth's atmosphere, as shown by the variability in abundances of trace gases like carbon dioxide and methane. In return, changes in the atmospheric trace gas composition affected Earth's climate. Studying compositional variations of the past atmosphere helps us understand the history of interactions between global biogeochemical cycles and Earth?s climate. The most reliable information on past atmospheric composition comes from analysis of air entrapped in polar ice cores. This project aims to generate ice-core records of relatively short-lived, very-low-abundance trace gases to determine the range of past variability in their atmospheric levels and investigate the changes in global biogeochemical cycles that caused this variability. This project measures three such gases: carbonyl sulfide, methyl chloride, and methyl bromide. Changes in carbonyl sulfide can indicate changes in primary productivity and photosynthetic update of carbon dioxide. Changes in methyl chloride and methyl bromide significantly impact natural variability in stratospheric ozone. In addition, the processes that control atmospheric levels of methyl chloride and methyl bromide are shared with those controlling levels of atmospheric methane. The measurements will be made in the new ice core from the South Pole, which is expected to provide a 40,000-year record.

The primary focus of this project is to develop high-quality trace gas records for the entire Holocene period (the past 11,000 years), with additional, more exploratory measurements from the last glacial period including the period from 29,000-36,000 years ago when there were large changes in atmospheric methane. Due to the cold temperatures of the South Pole ice, the proposed carbonyl sulfide measurements are expected to provide a direct measure of the past atmospheric variability of this gas without the large hydrolysis corrections that are necessary for interpretation of measurements from ice cores in warmer settings. Furthermore, we will test the expectation that contemporaneous measurements from the last glacial period in the deep West Antarctic Ice Sheet Divide ice core will not require hydrolysis loss corrections. With respect to methyl chloride, we aim to verify and improve the existing Holocene atmospheric history from the Taylor Dome ice core in Antarctica. The higher resolution of our measurements compared with those from Taylor Dome will allow us to derive a more statistically significant relationship between methyl chloride and methane. With respect to methyl bromide, we plan to extend the existing 2,000-year database to 11,000 years. Together, the methyl bromide and methyl chloride records will provide strong measurement-based constraints on the natural variability of stratospheric halogens during the Holocene period. In addition, the methyl bromide record will provide insight into the correlation between methyl chloride and methane during the Holocene period due to common sources and sinks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Polar ice sheets contain ancient air that can be extracted and analyzed for determining the composition of the past atmosphere. This grant funded the ice core research laboratory at the University of California, Irvine (UCI) to analyze air extracted from a new ice core drilled at the South Pole, Antarctica. The UCI ice core research laboratory specializes in measurements of atmospheric gases that are found at extremely low levels (ultra-trace gases). The ambient concentrations of ultra-trace gases range from 1000 to 1 molecules per one trillion nitrogen molecules. Our aim is to use the ancient air trapped in the polar ice sheets to determine how the concentrations of some of these rarest constituents of our atmosphere changed over time to study various environmental changes that take place on our planet. The time scales of interest range from 100 to thousands of years before present. The primary objective of this project was to make measurements three ultra-trace level gases - carbonyl sulfide (COS), methyl chloride (CH3Cl), and methyl bromide (CH3Br) - using samples from the South Pole ice core. 

COS is the most abundant sulfur gas in the troposphere and a precursor of sulfate aerosols in the stratosphere (atmosphere above 15 km altitude) where sulfate aerosols play a role in controlling the climate by blocking some of the sun's radiation. COS is emitted predominantly from oceanic sources and during wildfires. It is removed from the atmosphere via uptake by terrestrial plants. The uptake of COS by terrestrial plants is tightly coupled to photosynthesis by green land plants, which also results in uptake of atmospheric carbon dioxide. CH3Cl is the most important natural source of stratospheric chlorine and it is emitted by tropical plants and during wildfires. Chlorine facilitates ozone depletion in the stratosphere and impacts climate. CH3Br is a source of stratospheric bromine, which is more reactive than chlorine in the stratosphere. 

Prior to this project, the existing ice core data for COS, CH3Cl, and CH3Br were mostly limited to the last 2-3 thousand years before present and the data sets that reached further back in time did not allow proper assessments of the relationship between the atmospheric concentrations of these gases and the changes in global environmental parameters. With the measurements conducted under this project, this fact has now changed. We generated high-resolution atmospheric records that cover the 12 thousand years before present (the last interglacial period named the Holocene) and a 30 thousand year period from 23 to 52 thousand years ago during the last glacial period. This are the first-ever measurements of these gases at unprecedent quality and resolution.      

We find that COS and CH3Cl are highly correlated throughout most of the Holocene over short and long periods. The only explanation for this is that the observed variability in both trace gases is caused by changes in global wildfires. The second prominent feature of the data set is that the long-term changes in the COS record from the last glacial period are correlated with known periods of significant natural changes in global climate. 

The results indicate that there were large changes in gas emissions from wildfires during the Holocene.  This is a novel and unexpected finding, which has implications for all atmospheric trace gases emitted from wildfires, including gases with very large greenhouse warming potentials such as methane and carbon dioxide. We also find that there were likely climate driven changes in the primary productivity of terrestrial plants during the last glacial period. These findings are likely to have impacts in modeling of climate driven changes in various global environmental systems in the past and into the future. 

This project also had major educational and outreach impacts. It has contributed to the education, training, and professional development of several junior level researchers. The project supported the dissertation research of one graduate student at UCI who got extensive training from the PI about analytical chemistry techniques. The project also provided hands-on laboratory research experience opportunity to 10 undergraduate students from UCI, 2 other undergraduates from a local community college and from an out of state institution, and one high school student. Most of the undergraduate students have graduated with BS degrees in physical sciences and some are attending graduate school, pursuing a PhD degrees in related fields. One undergraduate student wrote a senior research thesis as part his involvement in this project. Another one was hired as a junior specialist to help with the analyses of the ice cores after graduation. During the grant period, the UCI ice core laboratory participated in various outreach activities geared towards introducing teachers and students of local high schools to cutting edge polar research. The outreach activities involved several lectures, laboratory tours, and experimental demonstrations annually that were led by the PI and the junior researchers involved in the project.
